title: 111_hr4183
content: The "Helping Unemployed Workers Act" is a temporary extension of certain unemployment benefits. The "Helping Unemployed Workers Act" extends emergency unemployment compensation and additional regular compensation until March 31, 2011 and April 1, 2011 respectively. The "Helping Unemployed Workers Act" extends emergency unemployment compensation and additional regular compensation until March 31, 2011 and April 1, 2011 respectively. It also adjusts dates for full funding of extended benefits under the Assistance for Unemployed Workers and Struggling Families Act. SEC. 3. Funding for temporary extension of certain unemployment benefits is amended to include specific amendments from various acts. SEC. 4. Temporary financing of certain short-time compensation programs. The Secretary will establish a program to make payments to States with certified short-time compensation programs for unemployment compensation within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Programs must meet specific requirements for certification. The program requires participating employers to comply with an approved written plan, certify that benefits under a defined benefit pension plan are not affected, and ensure union agreement for implementation. Full reimbursement is subject to specific conditions. The program requires employers to follow specific conditions for full reimbursement of benefits paid to individuals under the short-time compensation program. States must submit an application for certification to receive 100 percent reimbursement for benefits paid from the date of certification to December 31, 2011. The Secretary will notify the State agency of findings on compliance with program requirements. If the program meets the criteria, the State will be certified and eligible for reimbursement. Payments to States will be made as reimbursements under specific terms. The Secretary will notify the State agency of compliance findings. Payments to States will be made as reimbursements based on estimated amounts for each calendar month. Payment limitations include no payments for benefits exceeding 26 weeks under a short-time compensation program. No payments will be made for benefits paid to an individual by an employer. Under this section, benefits are paid to individuals by the State through a short-time compensation program if the individual is employed by an employer whose workforce has been reduced by temporary layoffs of more than 20 percent, on a seasonal, temporary, or intermittent basis, or engaged in a labor dispute. The Secretary may limit the frequency of employer participation in the program. Compliance oversight is conducted for participating employers. Under this section, participating employers must comply with the approved written plan, including retaining participating employees. The Secretary will establish oversight to ensure compliance. Funding will be provided as necessary for the program. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Labor. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Labor. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands. The terms "State agency" and "week" have specific meanings as defined in the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970.
